title: Aluminum rose to 2,914.35 USD/T on Dec. 18; one‑month and yearly gains noted
summary: Trading Economics reports aluminum price rose to 2,914.35 USD/tonne on December 18, 2025, reflecting a one‑month increase of about 3.6% and a year‑on‑year gain near 15.8%. The brief also notes prices are near a one‑month high amid improving demand prospects and tight global supply conditions.

title: Aluminum Prices Hit 3‑Year High: Is It the Next Key Metal in the Clean‑Energy Shift?
summary: CarbonCredits.com reports aluminum trading around $2,800–$2,900/tonne and hitting a 3‑year high, driven by rising demand from EVs, solar and grid upgrades and tighter supply from Chinese smelter output limits and Guinea bauxite disruptions. The article highlights falling LME inventories and growing premiums for low‑carbon aluminum, which could spur recycling and renewables‑powered smelter investment.

title: SMM Flash News: Secondary aluminum ingot social inventory drops on Dec 19
summary: SMM's flash updates (carried by Metal.com) report combined daily inventories of secondary aluminum ingots fell in mid‑December, supporting expectations that aluminum prices will remain elevated in the short term. The bulletin cites inventory declines and short‑term tightness as reasons for prices to 'mainly hover at highs.'

title: US Midwest aluminum premium hits record high
summary: Reporting from Metal.com based on SMM data, the US Midwest spot premium for aluminum surged to a record 88.10 cents per pound (about $1,942 per tonne), reflecting tight domestic availability and elevated regional spreads. The piece links the premium surge to strong demand and constrained secondary supply.

title: China aluminium imports decline 14% y/y, custom data shows
source: Hellenic Shipping News (from Chinese customs data)
summary: Hellenic Shipping News reports China’s imports of unwrought aluminum and aluminum products fell 14% year‑on‑year in November, according to customs data, suggesting weaker import flows that may tighten physical availability and support prices amid domestic production constraints.

title: 2025 Aluminum Scrap Market Review: Tariffs, Fires, and a Challenging Year
summary: IndexBox reviews 2025 scrap aluminum market dynamics, noting U.S. Section 232 tariff increases and major disruptions (including fires) have reshaped scrap flows and raised Midwest premiums, with uncertain demand into 2026. The analysis highlights transport cost pressures, export demand from Asia, and uneven consumption that could influence secondary supply and price formation.

title: AM Green and Mitsui & Co., Ltd. sign MoU to explore strategic collaboration
summary: AM Green and Mitsui & Co., Ltd. have signed a Memorandum of Understanding to explore strategic collaboration on low-carbon aluminum production, including potential investments in AM Green Metals' 1 MTPA primary aluminum smelter and 2 MTPA alumina refining operations powered by renewables. The partnership aims to support equity needs for the world’s first integrated green aluminum platform and explore offtake agreements and supply of auxiliary materials. This follows AM Green's prior MoU with the Andhra Pradesh government for a 1 MTPA green aluminum complex.

title: Smelter's future secured but cost to taxpayers unclear
source: My All Coast News of the Area
summary: The Australian federal government has confirmed taxpayer support to keep the troubled Tomago aluminum smelter running beyond 2028, securing over 1,000 jobs amid spiraling energy costs. Arrangements include fixed-price power purchase agreements and concessional finance for renewable energy projects, with Tomago Aluminium committing at least $1 billion for upgrades and decarbonization. The smelter produces up to 590,000 tonnes of aluminum annually, where electricity accounts for 40% of operating costs.

title: Hydro's power contract
summary: Hydro and Hafslund Kraft AS have signed a new long-term power purchase agreement to support aluminum production operations. This deal addresses energy needs critical for smelting capacity amid industry challenges.

title: Advanced sorting technologies drive innovation in aluminum recycling
summary: A webcast overview describes how X-ray transmission (XRT), Dynamic LIBS and deep-learning sorting systems are increasing purity and recovery of aluminum scrap, enabling recovery of higher-value alloy series and supporting circularity initiatives by companies like Novelis.[1]

title: CMR Green improves aluminum purity with German Steinert's technology
summary: CMR Green has partnered with Steinert GmbH to deploy sensor-based induction, X-ray and eddy-current sorting across its 12 plants, improving aluminum alloy purity and operational stability while cutting CO2 relative to primary metal production and supporting India's circular economy goals.[2]

title: Building reuse into the materials around us
summary: An MIT feature highlights advances in directing aluminum scrap into higher-value applications using AI-driven alloy blending, automated sensor sorting and improved melting practices, and discusses broader materials-circularity research including recovery from red mud and optimized alloy production.[5]

title: Modern recycling meets AI
summary: The article reports on investments in AI for visual sorting, machine monitoring and analytics in recycling facilities—capacity upgrades that will help recyclers process evolving packaging and increase the quality of recovered materials including aluminum feedstocks.[7]

title: EUR 58 million REMET plant to boost aluminium recycling in Hungary
summary: REMET Hungary is building a €58 million alloy recycling facility using advanced US processing technology; the plant aims to operate as a closed system with substantially lower energy use than primary production and will add regional capacity for recycled aluminum alloys.[4]

title: Hydro earns global recognition for aluminium recycling innovation
summary: Hydro reports winning Dezeen Awards for material innovation and sustainability for its aluminum recycling work, highlighting industry recognition of technological and design advances that improve circularity and material performance.[6]

title: Alcoa, Ball and Unilever pilot 'carbon-free' smelting technology in personal and home care packaging
summary: Alcoa, Ball and Unilever are piloting Elysis (carbon-free smelting) technology to produce aluminum for personal- and home-care packaging, aiming to eliminate process GHGs from smelting and lower lifecycle carbon footprints of aluminum packaging.[9]

title: U.S. Recycled Steel Prices Rise in December 2025 After Subdued Period
summary: U.S. recycled steel prices increased in December 2025 following a subdued period from May to November, driven by severe weather disruptions causing supply bottlenecks. Davis Index reported a $10 per ton rise for prime and prompt grades, and up to $20 per ton for other grades like shredded and HMS. Export prices from New York to Turkey also rose from $305 to $331.25 per metric ton by December 10.

title: HRC Steel - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
summary: HRC Steel price fell slightly to 906.03 USD/T on December 19, 2025, down 0.11% from the previous day, after dropping to 906.08 USD/T on December 18. Over the past month, prices rose 5.97% but remain volatile, with forecasts expecting 911.35 USD/T by quarter-end and 997.25 in 12 months. Historical highs reached 1945 USD/T in 2021.

title: Tighter supply lends support to global steel market
summary: BMI forecasts global average steel prices to rise to $US625 per tonne in 2026 from $US600 in 2025, driven by tighter supply from reduced Chinese output and easing exports. China's crude steel production is expected to fall 4% to 936 million tonnes in 2026 after a 3% decline in 2025, due to capacity curbs. Lower iron ore prices support margins but do not lead to cheaper steel amid reduced output.

title: U.S. Raw Steel Production Rises 5.3% Year-on-Year in Mid-December 2025
summary: U.S. raw steel production reached 1.753 million net tons in the week ending Dec. 13, 2025, a 5.3% increase versus the same week in 2024, with capability utilization at 76.5%. Year-to-date adjusted production through Dec. 13, 2025 was reported at 85.881 million net tons, a 3.4% rise from the prior year, driven primarily by strong regional contributions led by the Southern district.

title: Tighter supply lends support to global steel market
summary: Market analysis says global steel prices are expected to rise modestly in 2026 amid supply tightening as Chinese crude steel output is forecast to fall (about 4% in 2026 after a 3% decline in 2025), reflecting efforts to rein in excess capacity; this reduced output is expected to tighten markets and support higher prices despite subdued iron ore levels. The piece highlights policy-driven capacity cuts in China (including decommissioning rules) and notes iron ore supply growth from new projects like Simandou influencing raw-material dynamics.

title: AD/CVD News: Corrosion-Resistant Steel, Molded Fiber Products, Quartz, Silicon, Solar Cells
summary: The International Trade Administration and/or ITC announced antidumping and countervailing duty actions affecting corrosion‑resistant steel from multiple countries, with AD orders and CVD orders taking effect Dec. 19, 2025; the roundup also covers related trade remedy determinations across several product categories. The report is a summary of recent AD/CVD developments relevant to steel trade and import measures in the U.S.

title: Steel industry supplier P.C. Campana moving manufacturing line to Vicksburg
summary: P.C. Campana Inc., a supplier to the steel industry, will invest $3.43 million to relocate two manufacturing lines to Vicksburg, Mississippi, over the next three years, creating an estimated 17 jobs within five years and improving service to southern U.S. steelmakers. The move is supported by the Mississippi Development Authority and incentives under the MFLEX program.

title: Iron ore extends gains on improving steel margins, restocking hopes
summary: Iron ore futures extended gains driven by improved steel margins and expectations of restocking among steel producers, supporting higher feedstock demand. The article links commodity movements to steel sector margin improvements and broader market sentiment about inventory replenishment.

title: Steel Imports Down 16.7% In September vs. August
summary: AISC reported that total steel imports fell 16.7% in September versus August and that over the 12 months to Sept. 2025 total and finished steel imports were down 5.9% and 8.4%, respectively, compared with the prior 12 months—indicative of changing trade flows and domestic production dynamics. The analysis presents recent import trends that affect U.S. steel capacity utilization and market balance.

title: Green Steelmaking Innovation: Tech & Climate Impact 2025
summary: Green steelmaking with hydrogen technology is revolutionizing manufacturing by cutting emissions by 85-95% and challenging traditional blast furnaces. The article highlights the HYBRIT initiative in Europe as a leader in commercial-scale hydrogen-based production, alongside corporate sustainability mandates and infrastructure investments driving demand. It discusses challenges like infrastructure needs but notes cost reductions making renewable hydrogen competitive.

title: CMC's 2025 Sustainability Report and ESG Leadership in the Steel Sector Catalyst for Long-Term Value Creation
summary: CMC's 2025 Sustainability Report emphasizes its circular economy model using 100% recycled scrap steel in green micro mills, significantly reducing carbon footprint compared to blast furnaces. The company achieved a 6.5% energy intensity reduction since 2019 through innovations like the Q-One power system and renewable energy integration. This ESG strategy drives financial gains, including $239M+ EBITDA growth, positioning sustainability as a value driver.

title: Global Green Steel Market to Grow at a 14.8% CAGR During 2026-32
summary: Technological advancements like hydrogen-based DRI, EAF with renewables, and AI/IoT optimization are accelerating green steel production, reducing emissions while scaling efficiently. Leaders include SSAB's HYBRIT for fossil-free steel, Nucor's Econiq line, Tata Steel's EAF modernization, and ArcelorMittal's XCarb program. Factors like decarbonization policies and renewable investments boost the market, despite challenges in carbon accounting standardization.

title: From Traditional to Green Steel: Fifteen Years of Geosteel's Industrial Development
summary: Geosteel marks fifteen years of transitioning from traditional to green steel production. In 2025, the company replaced key machinery with more efficient technologies to enhance sustainability. This modernization supports broader industrial development in green steel practices.

title: U.S. November Inflation Pulls Back Beyond Expectations, LME Copper Fluctuates and Closes Lower Overnight
summary: SMM reports that LME copper opened around $11,726/tonne and after intraday swings closed slightly lower as traders weighed softer U.S. November inflation data that increased hopes for an earlier Fed rate cut; spot cathode supply remains ample while downstream demand is cautious, putting near-term upside under pressure. The piece also notes SHFE and secondary copper price moves and describes modest changes in spot premiums and market liquidity.

title: Copper prices diverge as investors weigh US rate outlook, AI boom
summary: Reuters reports copper prices showed mixed moves as markets balanced expectations for U.S. interest rates against robust demand themes from AI-led investment in data centres and electrification; the article highlights investor uncertainty on the rate path as a key driver of short-term divergence. Market commentary also places the price action in the context of wider base metals performance.

title: Latest updates on metals prices worldwide at 0200 GMT, Dec. 19
summary: Xinhua published a market snapshot from LSEG showing copper at $5.37 per lb (COMEX reference) as of 0200 GMT on Dec. 19, 2025, summarizing headline price levels across major metals. The brief bulletin is a price update rather than an in-depth market analysis.

title: Viewpoint: Copper supply tightness beckons in Europe
summary: Argus assesses 2025 fundamentals and argues that despite a strong price rally driven by mine disruptions and structural demand (grids, electrification, data centres), European market tightness is emerging with cathode premiums rising sharply and trader offers moving higher—signaling expectations of continued strength into early 2026. The piece provides regional supply/price detail and cites elevated premiums from major suppliers as evidence of tightening.

title: Copper drifts down as traders trim positions, await US data
summary: A market note summarizes that copper, after gaining roughly 33% in 2025 and touching record highs, eased as traders reduced positions ahead of key U.S. data; analysts still see underlying support but near-term profit-taking and macro data risks weigh on prices. The story frames the pullback as part of a broader risk-off/positioning dynamic rather than a change in structural demand drivers.

title: Copper: Price, Chart, Historical Data and Recent News
summary: TradingEconomics notes copper was trading around $5.36–$5.37 per lb in mid-December 2025, up significantly year-on-year and supported by strong demand from China and U.S. AI-driven investment; the page compiles recent intraday moves, month-to-date gains, and short news snippets on rebounds and falls tied to positioning and macro releases. This is a continuously updated market data and commentary page rather than a single authored article.

title: Kenadyr Metals Completes TSXV Reactivation, Name Change to Algo Grande Copper and 100% Acquisition of the Adelita Project
summary: Algo Grande Copper, formerly Kenadyr Metals, has acquired 100% interest in the 5,895-hectare Adelita Copper-Gold-Silver Project in the Arizona-Sonora copper belt. The project features the high-grade Cerro Grande skarn discovery, with an inaugural drilling program underway and plans for Phase 2 drilling in Q2 2026 targeting expansions and porphyry sources. The company expects TSXV reactivation on or about December 23, 2025, under symbol ALGR.

title: Lundin Mining to exit US nickel through Eagle sale to Talon
summary: Canadian miner Lundin Mining has agreed to sell its Eagle nickel/copper mine and Humboldt mill in the US to Talon Metals. This transaction allows Lundin to exit its US nickel operations. The deal supports Talon's aim to create a pure-play American nickel-copper company.

title: Stark drilling extends sedimentary copper
source: Mining News North / North of 60 Mining News
summary: Stark Copper's drilling has extended sedimentary copper mineralization at its project. The results confirm expansion of the copper system north of 60. Updated December 18, 2025.

title: Freeport Provides Update on Restart Plans for Grasberg Minerals District
summary: Freeport-McMoRan provided an update on phased restart plans for the Grasberg minerals district, expecting increased copper and gold production in 2026. The ramp-up involves PT Freeport Indonesia (PTFI) operations. This development impacts future copper output from the district.

title: Optimism persists in Queensland amid copper smelter, coal royalty issues
summary: Industry optimism continues in Queensland despite challenges with copper smelter developments and coal royalty issues. Queensland accounts for about half of relevant production. The article highlights ongoing positive sentiment in the sector.

title: Lundin Mining Announces Sale of the Eagle Mine and Humboldt Mill to Talon Metals to Create a Pure Play American Nickel-Copper Company
summary: Lundin Mining announced the sale of its Eagle Mine and Humboldt Mill to Talon Metals, enabling Talon to become a pure-play American nickel-copper company. This mirrors the Mining Weekly report on the same transaction. The move shifts US nickel-copper assets.

title: Nickel - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
summary: Nickel fell to 14,796 USD/T on December 19, 2025, down 0.43% from the previous day. Over the past month, prices have risen 2.36%. Forecasts indicate nickel expected to trade at 14,577.89 USD/MT by quarter-end and 13,795.43 in 12 months.[1]

title: On December 19, the SMM #1 refined nickel price was ...
summary: The SMM #1 refined nickel price reached 116,500–123,700 yuan/mt on December 19, averaging 120,100 yuan/mt, up 3,500 yuan/mt from the previous day. This reflects a rebound in spot prices amid market fluctuations.[2]

title: FLASH: Indonesia releases benchmark prices for nickel ore in December period I
summary: Indonesia's Nickel Miners Association set benchmark nickel ore prices at $14,666.67/wmt for early December 2025, down 2.21% from late November. Prices by grade range from $25.93/wmt for 1.6% Ni to $40.04/wmt for 2.0% Ni, all lower than prior period.[4]

title: Gold Nears Record High on Rate Cut Bets
summary: Nickel prices surged after reports of Indonesia considering a sharp cut to nickel ore production in 2026. This potential supply reduction boosted market sentiment amid broader metals movements.[6]

title: Lundin Mining to exit US nickel through Eagle sale to Talon
summary: Lundin Mining agreed to sell its Eagle nickel/copper mine and Humboldt mill in the US to Talon Metals in a share-based deal. This transaction marks Lundin's exit from US nickel operations.[8]

title: Canada Nickel Announces Initial Resources at Midlothian and Bannockburn Projects
summary: Canada Nickel has announced initial mineral resources for its Midlothian and Bannockburn projects in the Timmins Nickel District, expanding total Measured & Indicated Resources to 3.9 billion tonnes at 0.24% nickel containing 9.4 million tonnes of nickel. Midlothian delivers a 595 million tonnes Inferred Resource at 0.28% nickel, the highest grade to date, while Bannockburn establishes 63 Mt Indicated at 0.28% nickel and 129 Mt Inferred at 0.27% nickel. The company highlights the world-class potential of the district and plans further resource publication.

title: Lundin Mining to sell Eagle nickel-copper mine to Talon Metals for about $84 million
summary: Lundin Mining has agreed to sell its Eagle nickel-copper mine and Humboldt mill in the US to Talon Metals for approximately $84 million in a share-based transaction. This sale marks Lundin Mining's exit from US nickel production. The deal aims to create a pure-play American nickel-copper company for Talon Metals.

title: Lundin Mining to exit US nickel through Eagle sale to Talon
summary: Canadian miner Lundin Mining has agreed to sell its Eagle nickel/copper mine and Humboldt mill in the US to Talon Metals in a share-based deal. This transaction represents Lundin Mining's complete exit from the US nickel sector. The sale supports Talon's focus on domestic nickel production.

title: Deep Source delays Indonesia nickel acquisition to 2026, secures fresh funding
summary: Hong Kong-listed Deep Source Holdings Limited has delayed the completion of its planned acquisition of an Indonesian nickel asset to 2026 while securing fresh funding. The delay impacts their expansion in Indonesia's nickel sector. The company continues to target growth amid Indonesia's nickel production landscape.

title: Lundin Mining Announces Sale of the Eagle Mine and Humboldt Mill to Talon Metals to Create a Pure Play American Nickel-Copper Company
summary: Lundin Mining has announced the sale of its Eagle Mine and Humboldt Mill to Talon Metals, positioning Talon as a pure-play American nickel-copper company. The transaction involves key US nickel production assets. This move allows Lundin to refocus its portfolio outside US nickel.

title: Nickel Supply Woes: Innovations Steering a Sustainable EV Future
summary: Analysis of how high-nickel NMC batteries are driving global nickel demand and the innovations (like LFP expansion, sodium‑ion batteries, smaller EV batteries, and recycling) that could reduce nickel dependence and improve supply-chain sustainability. The piece also highlights efforts by juniors and projects (e.g., Alaska Energy Metals Corporation’s Nikolai project) aiming to secure more sustainable nickel sources for the U.S. transition to electric vehicles.

title: Green nickel for sustainable electrification: Carbon-free process extracts nickel for batteries and steel
source: Tech Xplore (reporting on Max Planck Institute research)
summary: Reports on Max Planck Institute for Sustainable Materials researchers who developed a carbon-free, hydrogen‑plasma extraction method that can extract nickel in a single step, cut CO2 emissions and energy use, and enable use of low‑grade ores; the team intends to scale the process toward industrial application. The method was published in Nature and positioned as a way to avoid shifting emissions from transport to metallurgy as nickel demand rises.

title: How nickel mining will be essential for powering the clean energy transition
summary: Overview of nickel’s critical role in lithium‑ion batteries and clean energy technologies, plus industry efforts to lower the carbon footprint of nickel production through efficiency improvements, recycling, and commitments by Nickel Institute members to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The article also reviews recycling rates and the sector’s potential to improve sustainability across the value chain.

title: Will Nickel Replace Lithium? The High‑Stakes Race for Next‑Gen Battery Dominance
summary: Analysis of emerging nickel‑based battery technologies (including nickel‑rich cathodes and NiMH variants) that could expand nickel’s role in energy storage, alongside discussion of sustainability challenges such as mining impacts and energy‑intensive refining; highlights trends like eco‑friendly mining, recycling and solid‑state developments that could improve nickel’s environmental profile.

title: Breakthrough Tech Yields 99% Pure Nickel, Cobalt
summary: Report on a UNIST research team that developed an advanced recycling technique recovering over 95% of nickel and cobalt from waste batteries with >99% purity, reducing chemical use and wastewater compared with conventional wet processes; the work (published in Energy Storage Materials) is presented as a potentially transformative, more sustainable battery‑recycling solution.

title: FLASH: Jinchuan Nickel‑Cobalt Research & Design Institute makes breakthrough in reducing volume and weight of arsenic sulfide residue
summary: Short industry flash reporting a technical breakthrough by Jinchuan’s Nickel‑Cobalt Research & Design Institute that reduces the volume and weight of arsenic sulfide residue from processing, which could lower environmental liabilities and improve sustainability of nickel/cobalt refining operations.

title: Tenaris Hits 5% Treasury Threshold as Controlling Shareholder Launches Accelerated Share Disposal
summary: Tenaris has reached a 5% treasury threshold through repurchased ordinary shares. The controlling shareholder has filed an amendment to Schedule 13D and launched an accelerated share disposal. This development highlights recent financial maneuvers by the company and its major stakeholder.

title: Repurchased own ordinary shares reached 5% of Tenaris's voting rights; Tenaris's controlling shareholder files amendment to Schedule 13D
summary: Tenaris's repurchased ordinary shares have reached 5% of its voting rights. The controlling shareholder has filed an amendment to Schedule 13D in response to this milestone. This update reflects ongoing share repurchase activities and shareholder adjustments.
